subsection.title: Determinants and Row Operations
subsection.p: The key to computing determinants efficiently is to consider how determinants are affected when the entries of a matrix change. In particular, by elementary row operations.

First, consider the 2 \times 2 case. Let A = \begin{bmatrix} a \amp b \\ c \amp d \end{bmatrix} be a 2 \times 2 matrix, with determinant \det{A} = ad - bc. Consider how this determinant is affected by row operations.
It turns out these properties are true for determinants of any size matrix.

theorem.title: Determinants and elementary row operations
theorem.p: Let A be a square matrix, B be the matrix resulting from A after a single row operation. Then,

ol.li: If a multiple of row row is added to another row, then \det{B} = \det{A}.
If two rows are interchanged, then \det{B} = -\det{A}.
If one row is scaled by k \neq 0, then \det{B} = k \cdot \det{A}.

subsection.p: In particular, only row interchanges and scalings affect the value of the determinant.

subsection.title: Evaluating Determinants of Higher Order
subsection.p: The preceding properties of determinants leads to a method for evaluating determinants, which is particularly efficient for higher-order matrices. Consider a square matrix A. subsection.title: Determinants and Invertibility
subsection.p: The previous algorithm for evalauting determinants also provides theoretical insight into the relationship between invertibility and determinants.

If A is invertible, then all of the diagonal entries of A are pivots, and so the diagonal entries of U will all be non-zero. Otherwise, if A is not invertible, then at least one of the diagonal entires of U will be equal to 0. This implies that \det{U} = 0, and so \det{A} = 0 also. This proves the main theorem relating determinants and invertible matrices.

theorem.title: Invertible if and only if non-zero determinant
theorem.p: A square matrix A is invertible if and only if \det{A} \neq 0.

subsection.title: Number of Operations for Computing Determinants
subsection.p: Determinant of an n \times n matrix has order n!.
